ygData.subject: Re: Evolving Coordinated Quadruped Gaits with the HyperNEAT Generative Encoding

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=ncnh7lMBJmc1DkeFSSBOamAaMASEtyWLJtB27kjmPwoacfpu-GTG

We have actually been running biped evolution experiments recently at
UCF b=
ecause we would like to use it as a test domain in the future as
well.  In =
our efforts, we have learned a couple things that may answer
some questions=
:

First, leaky integrator neurons definitely work and work well.  They
can=
 produce oscillatory motion without a sine wave (or any kind of
oscillator)=
 input.  So there is no doubt that a sine wave is
unnecessary.  However, Je=
ff, if in your domain somehow leaky
integrators hurt that is interesting.  =
I wonder why that would be.

Second, the model morphology is critical.  You=
 cannot simply expect
any biped to walk.  Great care is necessary to ensure=
 that everything
about the model makes sense and is proportionate.  

We're=
 still in the midst of an extensive study, and we will let
everyone know al=
l the details when it's completed.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jef=
f Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> > Very interesting paper! :)
> 
> Thanks. I=
'm glad you enjoyed it.
> 
> > It reminds me about the experiments I made w=
ith HyperNEAT for
> > controlling biped robots. Did you try using leaky-int=
egrator based
> > neurons for the substrate?
> > I found them very useful f=
or generating
> > oscillation patterns. Substrates of leaky integrators wit=
h tanh()
> > activation functions produce oscillations much easier than oth=
ers.
> > Hm.. I should really try with robots with 3 legs or more. Getting
=
> > biped walking with HyperNEAT is perhaps too ambitious right now.
> 
> I=
 have thought a lot about your biped experiment. I'd be really
interested
>=
 in hearing your opinion, and that of anyone else on this list, as to why
>=
 your results were so different from mine. I found that it did not
take tha=
t
> much tuning to get HyperNEAT to evolve really good quadruped gaits.
But=
, as
> you note, it was much harder to evolve gaits in your biped setup.
> =

> I can suggest a few hypotheses as to what explains the difference.
These=
 are
> not mutually exclusive, and it might not be the case that any one of=

them
> explains most of the difference, but instead that they add up to th=
e
> difference. 
> 
> 1) Biped gaits are harder to evolve than quadruped ga=
its
> 2) The sine wave I provided made it really easy to evolve periodic
ga=
its.
> 3) Leaky integrators hurt performance for some reason
> 4) I used a =
PID-based setup, where the target angle was the output
of the
> neural net =
(and not the force to be applied)
> 
> There are other differences of cours=
e, such as the inputs and the
number of
> hidden nodes. 
> 
> I'll make a f=
ew comments on each hypothesis.
> 
> 1) Biped gaits are harder to evolve th=
an quadruped gaits.
> 
> This would be easy to test by simply trying a bipe=
d with my setup.
> Unfortunately, I have some other obligations that will p=
revent me from
> testing this anytime soon, but if you (or anyone else) wou=
ld like to
give it
> a try, that would be cool. I can send you the code I u=
sed. One would
just
> need to change the quadruped into a biped. Alternatel=
y, you could try to
> mimic my setup in your "Ultimate NEAT" ;-).
> 
> I do=
 have access to a huge computing cluster. So, if someone makes
the code
> m=
odifications to my setup (which I know compiles on our cluster) and
sends
>=
 them to me, I can do a batch of runs.
> 
> 2) The sine wave I provided mad=
e it really easy to evolve periodic gaits
> 
> This would be an easy test. =
You could just plug a sine as an input
into your
> biped. Note: I found tha=
t the period of the sine wave made a huge
> difference. If I made it too fa=
st or too slow, evolution basically
ignored
> the signal. Within the range =
of periods that worked, I found that I got
> different types of gaits with =
different period speeds. With slower
periods,
> I observed cool tortoise-li=
ke gaits with left-right symmetry. With
medium
> periods, I got the gaits i=
n the paper. With faster periods, I saw
slightly
> more frantic versions of=
 the gaits in the paper.
> 
> As a side note, I tried to evolve the period =
for a short while and
it was a
> miserable failure. I'd like to try that ag=
ain, and would be
interested to
> hear people's thoughts as to why it faile=
d. Maybe I'll describe that
attempt
> in another email. If someone out ther=
e is curious, let me know and
I'll send
> it out sooner rather than later.
=
> 
> 3) Leaky integrators hurt performance for some reason.
> 
> I did not =
try leaky integrators. Did you ever try your setup without
them?
> 
> I did=
 not try them because the default sigmoid neurons worked so
well out of
> t=
he box that I did not experiment with alternatives. Both Ken (during
> prel=
iminary conversations about the paper) and one of the papers'
reviewers
> a=
sked about leaky integrators, so there is clearly some interest out
there
>=
 in seeing how leaky integrators would compare to the neurons
> we used in =
the paper.
> 
> Do most of you feel leaky integrators would perform better?=
 Why? I have
> never worked with them, nor do I know that much about them, =
so I
don't have
> great instincts on this front. Is it possible that they c=
ould have made
> things worse in Petar's setup?
> 
> It would be cool to te=
st them out in my setup. Again, I won't be
able to get
> to this in the nea=
r future so if someone out there wants to swap
them in and
> give it a go, =
that would be interesting.
> 
> 4) I used a PID-based setup, where the targ=
et angle was the output
of the
> neural net (and not the force to be applie=
d).
> 
> I could not figure out whether your setup did this as well. What
w=
ere the
> outputs in your system?
> ---------
> 
> Do you think any/all of =
these hypotheses explain the difference in
results?
> What other likely hyp=
othesis am I missing (I am sure there are lots).
> 
> Thanks again for chec=
king out the paper,
> Jeff
> 
> PS. Tripods would be fun. I also think addi=
ng feet and a flexible torso
> would be interesting.
> 
> 
> 
> > 
> > Pete=
r
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
>=
 >> Hello all-
> >> 
> >> Ever since I first understood HyperNEAT I have wa=
nted to see how it
> > would
> >> perform at controlling legged robots.
> >=
> 
> >> A paper I wrote on that subject was just accepted, so I can share i=
t
> > with
> >> you now. 
> >> 
> >> A copy of the paper, and videos of the=
 simulated robots, can be
> > obtained
> >> here:
> >> 
> >> 
> > http://de=
volab.msu.edu/SupportDocs/EvolvingCoordinatedGaitsWithHyperNE
> > AT
> >> 
=
> >> 
> >> I hope you find it interesting. Please let me know what you thin=
k,
> > or if you
> >> have any questions.
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Here is the cite=
 and abstract:
> >> 
> >> Clune, J., Beckmann, B. E., Ofria, C., & Pennock,=
 R. T.
> >> Evolving coordinated gaits with the HyperNEAT generative encodi=
ng.
> >> 
> >> Proceedings of the IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computing S=
pecial
> > Section
> >> on Evolutionary Robotics, 2009. Trondheim, Norway. =
To appear.
> >> 
> >> Legged robots show promise for complex mobility tasks=
, such as
> > navigating
> >> rough terrain, but the design of their contro=
l software is both
> > challenging
> >> and laborious. Traditional evolutio=
nary algorithms can produce these
> >> controllers, but require manual deco=
mposition or other problem
> >> simplification because conventionally-used =
direct encodings have
> > trouble
> >> taking advantage of a problem's regu=
larities and symmetries. Such
> > active
> >> intervention is time consumin=
g, limits the range of potential
> > solutions, and
> >> requires the user =
to possess a deep understanding of the problem's
> >> structure. This paper=
 demonstrates that HyperNEAT, a new and
> > promising
> >> generative encod=
ing for evolving neural networks, can evolve
> > quadruped gaits
> >> witho=
ut manually decomposing the problem. Analyses suggest that
> > HyperNEAT is=

> >> successful because it employs a generative encoding that can more
> >=
 easily
> >> reuse phenotypic modules. It is also one of the first
> > neur=
oevolutionary
> >> algorithms that exploits a problem's geometric symmetrie=
s, which may
> > aid its
> >> performance. We compare HyperNEAT to FT-NEAT,=
 a direct encoding
> > control, and
> >> find that HyperNEAT is able to evo=
lve impressive quadruped gaits and
> > vastly
> >> outperforms FT-NEAT. Com=
parative analyses reveal that HyperNEAT
> > individuals
> >> are more holis=
tically affected by genetic operators, resulting in
> > better
> >> coordin=
ation of the quadruped's legs. Overall, the results suggest
> > that
> >> H=
yperNEAT is a powerful algorithm for evolving control systems for
> > compl=
ex,
> >> yet regular, devices, such as robots.
> >> 
> >>  
> >> 
> >> 
> >=
> 
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune
> >> 
> >> Digital Evolution Lab, Mic=
higan State University
> >>

> >> 
> >
